That is to say, in terms of characteristics, profundity, conventional truth, ultimate truth, incompleteness, completeness, lack of adornment, possession of adornment, remainder, no remainder, supremacy, and distinctions, the truth of cessation is discriminated.
What is meant by in terms of characteristics?

It refers to the non-arising of afflictions in the true suchness of the noble path, whether as the basis of cessation, the agent of cessation, or the nature of cessation, which are the characteristics of the truth of cessation.
As the World-Honored One said:
The eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind - in this place, name-and-form completely ceases without remainder.
He also said:

Therefore, you should now contemplate this place, namely, where the eye completely ceases, far removed from the perception of form, up to where the mind completely ceases, far removed from the perception of dharmas.
Based on this principle, it is shown that the cessation of contaminated dharmas in the true suchness of the object is the characteristic of the truth of cessation.
What is meant by profound?

It means that the ultimate cessation of those conditioned forces is such cessation. As for this cessation in relation to those conditioned forces, it cannot be said to be different, nor can it be said to be not different, nor can it be said to be both different and not different, nor can it be said to be neither different nor not different.
Why is this?
Because it is free from conceptual proliferation.
In this meaning, if conceptual proliferation arises, it is not right thought, not the path, not suchness, and also not skillful and expedient thought.
As the World-Honored One said:
The exhaustion, detachment, cessation, tranquility, and disappearance of these six sense bases, etc.

If one says it is different, or if one says it is not different, or if one says it is both different and not different, or if one says it is neither different nor not different, then one gives rise to conceptual proliferation in the absence of conceptual proliferation, and as long as there are six sense bases, there can be conceptual proliferation.
When the six sense bases cease, all frivolous discourse is cut off, which is precisely nirvÄá¹‡a.
What is meant by conventional?
It refers to the cessation attained by the worldly path that subdues the seeds. Therefore, the World-Honored One separately calls it a part of nirvÄá¹‡a.
What is meant by ultimate?
It refers to the cessation attained by the wisdom of the noble ones that completely eradicates the seeds.
What is meant by incomplete?

It refers to the cessation possessed by those still in training, either included in the fruit of stream-entry, or included in the fruit of once-returning, or included in the fruit of non-returning, and so forth.
What is meant by complete?
It refers to the cessation possessed by those no longer in training, included in the fruit of arhatship, and so forth.
What is meant by unadorned?
It refers to the cessation possessed by the arhat liberated by wisdom.
What is meant by adorned?
It refers to the cessation possessed by the arhat liberated in both ways, endowed with the three knowledges and the six supernormal powers, and so forth.
What is meant by with remainder?
It refers to cessation with remainder of support.
What is meant by without remainder?
It refers to cessation without remainder of support.
What is meant by the most excellent?
It refers to the cessation subsumed in the non-abiding nirvÄá¹‡a of Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, because they always abide in benefiting and gladdening all sentient beings.
What is meant by the distinctions?
They are the distinctions of remainderless, permanent severance, permanent emergence, permanent vomiting, exhaustion, separation from desire, cessation, quiescence, submergence, and so forth.
Why is it called remainderless?
Because of the other phrases.
Why is it called permanent emergence?
Because it permanently emerges from the entanglements.
Why is it called permanent vomiting?
Because it permanently vomits the latent tendencies.
Why is it called exhaustion?
Because the antidote of the path of seeing attains separation.
Why is it called separation from desire?
Because the antidote of the path of cultivation attains separation.
Why is it called cessation?
Because in the future, the suffering that is its fruit is not produced.
Why is it called quiescence?
Because in the present world, the suffering that is its fruit in the mind never occurs.
Why is it called submergence?
Because the remaining events are eternally extinguished and submerged.
Why is this cessation also called unconditioned?
Because it is free from the three characteristics.
Why is this cessation also called difficult to see?
Because it transcends the realm of the physical eye and the divine eye.
Why is this cessation also called non-turning?
Because it is permanently free from the turning of the various destinies.
Why is this cessation called not lowly?
Because it is free from the three kinds of craving.
Why is this cessation also called nectar?
Because it is free from the demon of the aggregates.
Why is this cessation also called without outflows?
Because it is permanently free from the demon of all afflictions.
Why is this cessation also called a dwelling place?
Because it is the basis for the experience of non-transgressive joy and bliss.
Why is this cessation also called an island?
Because it is cut off from the three realms.
Why is this cessation also called a great salvation?
Because it is able to prevent all the calamities of great suffering.
Why is this cessation also called a refuge?
Because it is the basis for the skillful means of a non-deceptive intention.
Why is this cessation called the supreme refuge?
Because it is the basis for the attainment of the supreme holy nature of all refuges.
Why is this cessation also called immortal?
Because it is eternally free from birth.
Why is this cessation called free from heat?
Because it is eternally free from the heat of all afflictions and eternally free from the great heat of the suffering of not obtaining what one seeks.
Why is this cessation called free from burning?
Because it is eternally free from all the afflictions of sorrow, lamentation, suffering, and distress.
Why is this cessation also called peaceful?
Because it is the basis for the abode of fearlessness.
Why is this cessation also called cool?
Because it is the basis for all beneficial matters.
Why is this cessation also called blissful?
Because it is the matter of the bliss of the ultimate truth.
Why is this cessation called auspicious?
Because it is the basis for attaining that which is easily cultivated.
Why is this cessation also called free from illness?
Because one is permanently separated from all obstacles and illnesses.
Why is this cessation also called immovable?
Because one is permanently separated from all scattered and agitated states.
Why is this cessation also called nirvana?
Because it is the basis for the abode of the great peace and bliss of signlessness.
Why is this cessation also called unborn?
Because it is separated from continuous birth.
Why is this cessation also called unarisen?
Because it is permanently separated from the gradual arising of this later [birth].
Why is this cessation also called uncreated?
Because it is permanently separated from the power that attracts all past karma and afflictions.
Why is this cessation also called unconditioned?
Because it does not create a basis for the present karma and afflictions.
Why is this cessation also called unproduced?
Because it is permanently separated from the continuous birth of the future.
Thus, the truth of cessation generally has four kinds of aspects, namely the aspect of cessation, the aspect of tranquility, the aspect of excellence, and the aspect of separation.
What is the aspect of cessation?
Because of being separated from afflictions.
What is the characteristic of tranquility?
Because it is free from the bonds of suffering.
What is the characteristic of excellence?
Because it is the activity of delighting in tranquility.
What is the characteristic of separation?
Because it is the activity of constant benefit.
What is the truth of the path?
It is that by which one knows suffering, severs the origination [of suffering], realizes cessation, and cultivates the path. This is the general characteristic of the truth of the path.
The path is of five kinds: the path of equipment, the path of preparation, the path of seeing, the path of cultivation, and the ultimate path.
What is the path of equipment?

It refers to the morality possessed by ordinary beings, guarding the sense-doors, knowing moderation in food and drink, always not sleeping in the first and last watches of the night, diligently cultivating tranquility and insight, and abiding in right knowledge.

Moreover, there are other wholesome practices, such as the wisdom derived from hearing, the wisdom derived from reflection, and the wisdom derived from cultivation. By cultivating these, one attains the state of being a vessel for the realization of liberation.
What is the path of preparation?
That is to say, there is a path of equipment that is also a path of application, or there may be a path of application that is not a path of equipment.

That is to say, for one who has already accumulated the path of equipment, there are the roots of goodness that are conducive to penetration, namely, the dharmas of heat, the dharmas of summits, the dharmas of acquiescence in accordance with the truths, and the supreme worldly dharmas.
What are the dharmas of heat?
That is to say, each individually realizes within the truths the attainment of illumination, samÄdhi, prajÃ±Ä, and the dharmas associated with them.
What are the dharmas of summits?
That is to say, each individually realizes within the truths the increase of illumination, samÄdhi, prajÃ±Ä, and the dharmas associated with them.
What are the dharmas of acquiescence in accordance with the truths?
That is to say, each individually realizes within the truths the partial entry into acquiescence, samÄdhi, prajÃ±Ä, and the dharmas associated with them.
What are the supreme worldly dharmas?
That is to say, each individually realizes within the truths the uninterrupted mind, samÄdhi, prajÃ±Ä, and the dharmas associated with them.
What is the path of seeing?
If it is spoken of in general terms, it refers to the samÄdhi of non-apprehension that arises immediately after the supreme worldly dharmas, prajÃ±Ä, and the dharmas associated with them.
Moreover, its characteristic is the knowledge of equality in the equality of the object and the subject of cognition.

Moreover, its characteristic is the knowledge of the object that eliminates the provisional reality of individual sentient beings, the provisional reality of dharmas, and the provisional reality of both.

If the differences in the path of seeing are spoken of separately, it refers to the receptivity to the knowledge of the dharma with regard to suffering, the knowledge of the dharma with regard to suffering, the receptivity to the knowledge of the subsequent cognition with regard to suffering, the knowledge of the subsequent cognition with regard to suffering, the receptivity to the knowledge of the dharma with regard to the origin [of suffering], the knowledge of the dharma with regard to the origin [of suffering], the receptivity to the knowledge of the subsequent cognition with regard to the origin [of suffering], the knowledge of the subsequent cognition with regard to the origin [of suffering], the receptivity to the knowledge of the dharma with regard to the cessation [of suffering], the knowledge of the dharma with regard to the cessation [of suffering], the receptivity to the knowledge of the subsequent cognition with regard to the cessation [of suffering], the knowledge of the subsequent cognition with regard to the cessation [of suffering], the receptivity to the knowledge of the dharma with regard to the path [leading to the cessation of suffering], the knowledge of the dharma with regard to the path [leading to the cessation of suffering], the receptivity to the knowledge of the subsequent cognition with regard to the path [leading to the cessation of suffering], and the knowledge of the subsequent cognition with regard to the path [leading to the cessation of suffering].
These sixteen knowledges and receptivities are the characteristics of the differences in the path of seeing.
What is suffering?
It refers to the truth of suffering.
What is the dharma of suffering?
It refers to the teachings that arise from the predominance of the truth of suffering.
What is dharma knowledge?
It refers to the knowledge of dharmas that observes the supreme truth on the path of preparation.
What is the acceptance of knowledge?

It refers to the acceptance of the knowledge of dharmas regarding the truth of suffering, which is the pure wisdom that directly realizes the truth of suffering, and by which one permanently abandons all the afflictions to be eliminated by seeing the truth of suffering.
What is the knowledge of dharmas regarding suffering?
It refers to the knowledge by which one attains liberation from the previously mentioned afflictions immediately after acceptance, and it is called the knowledge of dharmas regarding suffering.
What is the acceptance of the knowledge of the subsequent class of dharmas?

It refers to the arising of the pure wisdom immediately after the knowledge of dharmas regarding suffering, which individually realizes the acceptance of the knowledge of dharmas regarding suffering and the knowledge of dharmas regarding suffering.
It is said that all the subsequent holy dharmas are of the same class as this, and therefore it is called the acceptance of the knowledge of the subsequent class of dharmas.
What is the knowledge of the subsequent class of dharmas?

It refers to the arising of the pure knowledge immediately after this [acceptance], which confirms and seals the acceptance of the knowledge of the subsequent class of dharmas. This is called the knowledge of the subsequent class of dharmas.
In the same way, in the other truths, according to the case, all the patiences and knowledges should be understood.
In this stage, by the patiences and knowledges of dharmas one awakens to the grasped, and by the subsequent patiences and knowledges one awakens to the grasper.
Also, in this stage of all the patiences and knowledges, it is said that one abides in signless contemplation.
These sixteen moments of mind are called the path of insight.
The arising of knowledge with regard to the known is called a moment.
The truth of the path is to be understood through four aspects, i.e., as established, as reflection, as realization and experience, and as perfection.
What is meant by as established?

Sravakas, etc., having attained the ultimate with regard to their own realization, in order to cause others to understand it as well, by means of subsequently acquired knowledge establish the truth of the path through innumerable categories of names, phrases, and syllables.
What is meant by as reflection?
It is the correct cultivation of the expedient means of realization, contemplating and repeatedly practicing with worldly cognition as it is established.
What is meant by realization?

It means that after such repeated practice, one internally realizes and experiences for the first time the stage of emerging from the world, the stage of the correct path of seeing, the stage of no more conceptual proliferation.
What is meant by perfection?
It means that after this stage, one perfects the transformation of the basis, up to the attainment of the ultimate.
Having already attained the ultimate stage, one again uses the subsequent cognition to establish the truth of the path using the collection of names, phrases, and sentences.

As a sutra says, Far from dust and free from defilements, the Dharma eye is born in regard to all dharmas. This is said based on the path of seeing. The forbearances of all dharmas can be far from dust, and the cognitions of all dharmas can be free from defilements.
It is because of complete understanding and permanent abandonment that the path becomes pure.
As a sutra says:
Seeing the Dharma, attaining the Dharma, thoroughly penetrating the Dharma, ultimately firm in the Dharma, transcending all hopes and doubts, not relying on other conditions.
In the teachings of the Great Master, others cannot lead them. They attain fearlessness regarding all dharmas.
This is also said based on the path of seeing.
Seeing the Dharma refers to the forbearances regarding the [four] truths.
Attaining the Dharma refers to the knowledges regarding the [four] truths.
Utterly penetrating the Dharma refers to the forbearances regarding the subsequent [four] truths.
Ultimate firmness in the Dharma refers to the knowledges regarding the subsequent [four] truths.
Transcending all hopes is because the forbearances and knowledges regarding one's own realization are free from hope and worry.
Transcending all doubts is because in this stage, regarding the realizations of others, one is free from hesitation.
Not relying on other conditions means that in the path of cultivation, one is naturally skillful in the path without being led by others.
In the teachings of the Great Master, others cannot lead them means that they are not led by false paths in the teachings of the Buddha.
Attaining fearlessness regarding all dharmas means that regarding the Dharma to be explained based on one's own realization, all timid and inferior states of mind are permanently absent.

It refers to the worldly path, supramundane path, weak path, middling path, strong path, path of preparation, uninterrupted path, path of liberation, path of advancement, etc., that exist above the path of seeing. All of these are called the path of cultivation.
What is the worldly path?

It refers to the worldly first concentration, second concentration, third concentration, fourth concentration, sphere of infinite space, sphere of infinite consciousness, sphere of nothingness, and sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
These concentrations and formless [absorptions] should be extensively distinguished by means of four aspects: defiled, pure, established, and purified.
What is meant by defiled?
It refers to the four indeterminate roots:
one is craving, two is view, three is pride, four is ignorance.

Because of craving, the higher meditative absorptions are defiled by the defilements of taste. Because of views, the higher meditative absorptions are defiled by the defilements of views. Because of pride, the higher meditative absorptions are defiled by the defilements of pride. Because of ignorance, the higher meditative absorptions are defiled by the defilements of doubt.
In this way, these afflictions always taint the mind, causing the afflictions and secondary afflictions of the form and formless realms to continue and flow.
What is meant by pure?
It refers to the pure meditative absorptions and formless attainments, which are called pure because they are inherently wholesome.
What is meant by establishment?
There are four kinds of establishment: establishment of factors, establishment of meditative attainments, establishment of categories, and establishment of names and concepts.
What is establishment of factors?
It refers to the first meditative absorption having five factors.
What are the five?
First, investigation, second, analysis, third, joy, fourth, bliss, fifth, unification of mind.
The second meditative absorption has four factors.
What are the four?
First, inner purity; second, joy; third, pleasure; fourth, one-pointedness of mind.
The third concentration has five factors.
What are the five?
First, equanimity; second, mindfulness; third, clear comprehension; fourth, pleasure; fifth, one-pointedness of mind.
The fourth concentration has four factors.
What are the four?
First, purity of equanimity;
second, purity of mindfulness;
third, neither-pleasure-nor-painful feeling;
fourth, one-pointedness of mind.

Because of the factors of antidotes, the factors of benefit, and the factors of the nature that supports those two, the formless [absorptions] do not establish factors, because their nature is of the same flavor as Å›amatha.
How are the meditative absorptions established?
It is said that one enters the first concentration up to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception through seven kinds of attention.
What are called the seven kinds of attention?

That is, the attention of understanding characteristics, the attention of resolve, the attention of separation, the attention of delight, the attention of investigation, the attention of the culmination of practice, and the attention of the fruit of the culmination of practice.
What is the establishment of categories?
That is, the first meditation is cultivated in three categories of weak, medium, and strong.
As with the first meditation, the other meditations and formless [absorptions] are cultivated in three categories.
Because the first meditation is cultivated in weak, medium, and strong categories, three kinds of karmic results are born in the first meditation.
As with the first meditation, in the other meditations, whether cultivated or born as results, there are also three categories.
In the formless realm, there are no separate locations, so the distinction of locations for the born results is not established.
However, because the formless concentrations are cultivated in three categories, when their karmic results are born, there are high and low, inferior and superior.
What is the establishment of names?

That is to say, among the samÄdhis included in the first dhyÄna, the buddhas and bodhisattvas of great authority enter samÄdhis, the names of which are not even known to Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, let alone their being able to know their number.
How much less could they realize and enter them?
As in the samÄdhis included in the first dhyÄna, so it is in the samÄdhis included in the other dhyÄnas and formless [absorptions].
These explanations are all based on the perfection of dhyÄna.
What is meant by pure?
The samÄdhi at the limit of the first dhyÄna, up to the samÄdhi at the limit of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, this is called pure.
What is the supramundane path?

That is, the cognition of suffering, the cognition of origination, the cognition of cessation, and the cognition of the path, which are included in the class of cognition of dharmas and cognition of species in the path of cultivation, and the samÄdhi, etc. associated with them, are either included in the preliminary concentration or included in the first dhyÄna up to the sphere of nothingness. The sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is only worldly, because the unclear perception always occurs in it. For this reason, it is called the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
As the World-Honored One said:
Up to the samÄpatti of perception, one can truly illuminate and penetrate.
The concentration of cessation is also included in the supramundane, because it is realized after the noble path.

It can only be initiated in the human realm, and can be manifested either in the human realm or in the form realm. It is rarely manifested when reborn in the formless realm, because those abiding in the fruition of the liberation of tranquility rarely activate it with diligent effort.
Namely, the soft-soft, soft-medium, and soft-upper stages of the path.
By means of this path, one is able to abandon the upper-upper, upper-medium, and upper-soft three grades of afflictions in each stage of the three realms.
What is the medium path?
Namely, the medium-soft, medium-medium, and medium-upper stages of the path.
By means of this path, one is able to abandon the medium-upper, medium-medium, and medium-soft three grades of afflictions in each stage of the three realms.
What is the upper path?
Namely, the upper-soft, upper-medium, and upper-upper stages of the path.
By means of this path, one is able to abandon the soft-upper, soft-medium, and soft-soft three grades of afflictions in each stage of the three realms.
What is the path of preparation?
That by which one is able to abandon afflictions is called the path of preparation within the path of cultivation.
What is the uninterrupted path?
That by which one uninterruptedly and permanently abandons afflictions without remainder.
What is the path of liberation?
It is the liberation obtained by this path in the cessation of afflictions.
What is the path of progress?
The preparatory, uninterrupted, and liberated paths for the sake of eliminating the remaining categories of afflictions are called the path of progress.

Moreover, abandoning the preparatory effort for eliminating afflictions, either contemplating various dharmas with diligent effort, or diligently abiding in various dharmas, or cultivating other samÄdhis and all the paths, are called the path of progress.
Moreover, for the sake of manifesting superior qualities, or for the sake of abiding in various dharmas, all the paths are called the path of progress.
How does one cultivate these various paths?
It is cultivation through attainment, cultivation through practice, cultivation through removal, and cultivation through antidotes.
Cultivation through attainment refers to cultivating the arising of wholesome dharmas that have not yet arisen.
Cultivation through practice refers to cultivating the stability, non-forgetfulness, and further increase and expansion of wholesome dharmas that have already arisen.
Cultivation through removal refers to cultivating the complete elimination of unwholesome dharmas that have already arisen.
The cultivation of counteragents refers to the cultivation of non-arising of evil and unwholesome dharmas that have not yet arisen.
Moreover, when the path arises, it is able to establish its own habitual tendencies, which is called the cultivation of attainment.
The cultivation of this path in the present is called the cultivation of practice.
When this path is present, it is able to abandon its own obstacles, which is called the cultivation of removal.
Since this path has already abandoned its own obstacles, it causes them to abide in the future in a state of non-arising, which is called the cultivation of counteragents.

There are also four kinds of counteragents called the cultivation of counteragents, namely the counteragent of disgust and destruction, the counteragent of abandonment, the counteragent of upholding, and the counteragent of distancing.
What is the counteragent of disgust and destruction?
It refers to seeing many faults in contaminated conditioned phenomena.
What is the counteragent of abandonment?
It refers to the path of preparation and the uninterrupted path.
What is the counteragent of upholding?
It refers to the path of liberation.
What is the counteragent of distancing?
It refers to the subsequent paths.

Moreover, the distinctions of the path are of eleven kinds, namely, the path of observing phenomena, the path of diligent effort, the path of cultivating concentration, the path of expedient means for realizing the truths, the path of approaching realization of the truths, the path of realizing the truths, the path of pure deliverance, the path of distinctions based on faculties, the path of cultivating the three learnings, the path of manifesting various merits, and the path of comprehensively embracing all paths.

These various paths are established in sequence, namely, the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, the four kinds of right practices, the four kinds of Dharma traces, Å›amatha, vipaÅ›yanÄ, and the three roots of the taintless.
Herein, all the factors of enlightenment are established by means of five aspects, namely, object, essence, associates, cultivation, and fruits of cultivation.
The objects of the four establishments of mindfulness are the body, feelings, mind, and dharmas.
There are also four matters, namely, the matter of what I rely on, the matter of what I enjoy, the matter of my own body, and the matter of my defilements and purity.
The essence is wisdom and mindfulness.
The associates are the corresponding mind and mental factors, etc.
Cultivation refers to cultivating the contemplation of the body, etc. within one's own body, etc.
As with the internal, so with the external and the internal-external.
The internal body refers to the internal form aggregate within one's own body.
The external body refers to the external form aggregate outside one's own body.
The internal-external body refers to the external sense bases that are associated with the internal sense bases and are the support for the faculties.
Moreover, it refers to the internal form aggregate within another's body.
How does one cultivate the contemplation of the body within the body?
It means to contemplate the reflected image body and the substantial body equally.
Experiencing internal feelings means feelings that arise from one's own body.
External feelings means feelings that arise from another's body.
Internal-external feelings means feelings that arise from both one's own and another's body.
As with feelings, so with mind and dharmas.
As one cultivates contemplation of the body in the body, so one cultivates contemplation of feelings, etc. in feelings, etc. as appropriate.
Moreover, cultivation refers to desire, effort, exertion, vigor, indefatigability, right mindfulness, right cognition, and heedfulness, because they are the distinctions of cultivation.

The cultivation of desire is for the purpose of countering the secondary affliction of non-attention.ğŸ”½The cultivation of effort is for the purpose of countering the secondary affliction of laziness.

The cultivation of exertion is for the purpose of countering the secondary afflictions of torpor and restlessness.ğŸ”½The cultivation of vigor is for the purpose of countering the secondary affliction of mental inferiority.
The cultivation of indefatigability is for the purpose of countering the secondary afflictions of laxity and fatigue.
The cultivation of indefatigability is for the purpose of countering the secondary affliction of being content with merely a little wholesome dharma.
The cultivation of right mindfulness is for the purpose of countering the secondary affliction of forgetting the teacher's instructions.
The cultivation of right knowledge refers to the counteraction of the secondary defilement of remorse for transgressions.
The cultivation of heedfulness refers to the counteraction of the secondary defilement of abandoning the yoke of all good.
The fruits of cultivation refer to the abandonment of the four inversions, the entry into the four noble truths, and the freedom from the body, etc.
The object of the four right efforts refers to the counteracted and counteracting dharmas that have already arisen and those that have not yet arisen.
The essence refers to vigor.
The associates refer to the corresponding mind and mental factors, etc.
The cultivation is as stated in the sutra:
Arising desire, exertion, instigation, right effort, exertion of mind, and holding of mind.
Among these phrases, some manifest correct effort and its basis.
The basis refers to desire.
Correct effort refers to exertion, etc.
In order to reduce torpor and restlessness and instigate right effort with regard to the mental states of calming, uplifting, and equanimity, the sutra next says exertion of mind and holding of mind.
The result of cultivation refers to the complete abandonment of all that is to be eliminated.
Obtaining or increasing the antidotes is called the result of cultivation.
The object of the four bases of supernatural power is the function accomplished by perfected concentration.
The essence is samÄdhi.
The associates are desire, effort, mind, investigation, and the corresponding mind and mental factors, etc.
What is the samÄdhi of desire?
It refers to the one-pointedness of mind that is touched through earnest skillful means.
What is the samÄdhi of effort?
It refers to the one-pointedness of mind that is touched through uninterrupted skillful means.
What is the samÄdhi of mind?
It refers to the one-pointedness of mind that is touched through the power of previously cultivated samÄdhi.
What is the samÄdhi of investigation?
It refers to the one-pointedness of mind that is touched through internally discerning the teachings heard from others.
Moreover, the samÄdhi of desire means the one-pointedness of mind that is touched through giving rise to desire.

Diligence samÄdhi means that by means of exertion and effort, one touches the one-pointedness of mind.ğŸ”½Mind samÄdhi means that by means of holding the mind, one touches the one-pointedness of mind.
Contemplation samÄdhi means that by means of exerting the mind, one touches the one-pointedness of mind.
Cultivation means repeatedly cultivating the eight kinds of practices.
What are the eight?
They are desire, vigor, faith, serenity, right mindfulness, right knowledge, volition, and equanimity.
These eight are summarized into four: application, acceptance, continuity, and counteraction.

Moreover, desire, vigor, mind, and contemplation in cultivation are of two kinds: cultivation of distancing the gathering and scattering of causes and conditions, and cultivation of the support that is neither inferior nor scattered.

The fruit of cultivation means that because samÄdhi has been well cultivated, one is able to freely penetrate and transform according to one's wishes whatever dharmas one wishes to realize and penetrate.

Moreover, in the various dharmas in different places, one attains mastery and function, and according to one's wishes, one is able to accomplish various spiritual powers and other things, and is also able to give rise to superior qualities.
The objects of the five faculties are the four noble truths.
Their essence is faith, zeal, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom.
Their associates are the corresponding mind and mental factors, etc.

Cultivation means that the faculty of faith cultivates the practice of acquiescence towards the truths.ğŸ”½The faculty of zeal, having already acquiesced to the truths, cultivates the practice of exertion for the sake of realization.
The faculty of mindfulness, having already exerted zeal towards the truths, cultivates the practice of non-forgetfulness through focused mindfulness.
The faculty of concentration, having already focused mindfulness on the truths, cultivates the practice of one-pointedness of mind.
The faculty of wisdom, having already attained concentration on the truths, cultivates the practice of discernment.
As for the result of cultivation, it means being able to quickly give rise to the realization of the truths and to cultivate heat and summit, and to induce patience and the supreme worldly dharmas.
The five powers are also like this.

The three faculties are the faculty of understanding what has not been understood, the faculty of understanding, and the faculty of possessing complete understanding.

It refers to the faculties present in the path of preparation and in the fifteen moments of the path of seeing.

It refers to the faculties present in all the paths of training that come after the sixteenth moment of the path of seeing.
What is the faculty of possessing complete understanding?
It refers to the faculties present in the path of no-more-learning.
When one cultivates the path in the first trance state, one also cultivates the wholesome roots of the desire realm, because one has mastery over them.

What is the path of completion?

It is said that based on the vajra-like concentration, because all coarseness is forever extinguished, because all bonds are forever severed, and because one forever realizes the attainment of separation, one subsequently attains the knowledge of termination and the knowledge of non-production in immediate succession, and attains the ten dharmas of the adepts and so forth.

Because of being able to counteract the afflictions.

Because of being able to accomplish the mind and prevent it from being inverted.

Because of heading towards the traces of true permanence.

What is the difference between the mundane and supramundane?
